passage_text: Most people probably shouldn’t have pet capybaras. But a handful of people consider these “giant hamsters” to be the best pets ever. Melanie Typaldos is one of those people. “Capybaras are not the right pets for most people, or even for very many people,” writes Ms. Typaldos on her blog, Capybara Madness.

Also, they get quite large so I can't recommened them. They are probably insanely hard to take care of and keep happy. Remember, they are wild animals from the amazon, not domesticated pets like dogs, cats, and rabbits. If you want a pet though, you could always adopt a dog, cat, rabbit, or any other pet from a shelter. (and yes you can find lots of baby animals in shelters) The animals would likely also be aggresive.

For the video game developer, see Capybara Games. The capybara (Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris) is a large rodent of the genus Hydrochoerus of which the only other extant member is the lesser capybara (Hydrochoerus isthmius). The capybara is the largest rodent in the world.

The capybara, Hydrochoerus Hydrochaeris, is a semi-aquatic rodent of South America. It weighs about a hundred pounds, and is about 2 feet tall at the shoulder. Capybara Pet Capybaras are very family oriented creatures. They do not do as well alone, but with a friend… other animal to bond with it will be content.
The capybara is not a threatened species and is hunted for its meat, hide and also for a grease from its thick fatty skin which is used in the pharmaceutical trade.
